# Creating a New Node By Rendering To a Texture

**Article**

Render a portion of the node tree into a new texture.

## Overview

You can create a texture from some portion of on-screen content with [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKView/texture(from:)], or its variation, [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKView/texture(from:crop:)]. Both of these functions are available for scenes rendered by [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKView] or [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/WatchKit/WKInterfaceSKScene].

There are a couple reasons you might want to do this, for example:

- Creating a new sprite node whose texture reflects prior shading done with [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKShader]
- Flattening a hierarchy of nodes into a texture, either for performance, or to apply some effect. Note that this can also be done using [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKEffectNode] and setting [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKEffectNode/shouldRasterize] to true.
- Breaking appart an existing node into separate nodes, for example, for an explosion effect.

## Snapshotting Nodes to a Texture

- **texture(from:crop:)**: Renders a portion of a node’s contents and returns the rendered image as a texture.
- **texture(from:)**: Renders the contents of a node tree and returns the rendered image as a texture.
